---
title: "Effect Modification Analysis within the Propensity score Framework"
author: "Mohammad Ehsanul Karim"
format:
  html:
    toc: true
    number-sections: true
editor: visual
execute:
  cache: true
---





## Simulation

First, we need to install the R package `simcausal`, which can be obtained from GitHub:



::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-2_55e9987eb35fca9562bc92127f2473c4'}

```{.r .cell-code}
devtools::install_github('osofr/simcausal', build_vignettes = FALSE)
```
:::



We will use the following data-generation model:



::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-3_626112fbdc216b91c117da9b611396b1'}

```{.r .cell-code}
require(simcausal)
D <- DAG.empty()
D <- D + 
  node("age", distr = "rnorm", 
       mean = 2, sd = 4) + 
  node("gender", distr = "rbern", 
       prob = plogis(4)) +
  node("education", distr = "rbern", 
       prob = plogis(3 + 5* age)) +
  node("diet", distr = "rbern", 
       prob = plogis(1 -3 * education)) +
  node("income", distr = "rbern", 
       prob = plogis(2 - 5 * education - 4 * age)) +
  node("smoking", distr = "rbern", 
       prob = plogis(1 + 1.2 * gender + 2 * age)) +
  node("hypertension", distr = "rbern", 
       prob = plogis(1 + log(3) * diet + 
                       log(1.3) * age + 
                       log(3.5) * smoking + 
                       log(0.5) * gender))
Dset <- set.DAG(D)
plotDAG(Dset)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](chapter_07_files/figure-pdf/unnamed-chunk-3-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::



We can now generate an example dataset:



::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-4_a6aa31548bed1b8a207c2ae1753c3197'}

```{.r .cell-code}
Obs.Data <- sim(DAG = Dset, n = 50000, rndseed = 123)

Obs.Data$smoking <- as.character(Obs.Data$smoking)
Obs.Data$income <- as.factor(Obs.Data$income)
Obs.Data$income <- relevel(Obs.Data$income, ref = "1")
```
:::



Sample data from the hypothetical example of association between hypertension and smoking, where other variables such as income, age \[centered\], gender, education and diet also plays a role in the data generation process.



::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-5_9d5b708849c4a3a4eebf42fd84e7ac56'}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
            age gender education diet income smoking hypertension
34901 12.288936      1         1    1      0       1            1
149   10.400436      1         1    0      0       1            1
10060  2.991820      1         1    0      0       1            0
22220 -4.311952      0         0    0      1       0            1
9979  -6.435549      0         0    0      1       0            1
```
:::
:::



## Effect measure assessment via adding interaction term

Below, we estimate a logistic regression model to assess whether the effect of smoking (the exposure) on hypertension is modified by income. The covariates age and gender are confounders.



::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-6_8677e4bd607c703d8b2486908a6e4ad3'}

```{.r .cell-code}
fit.w.em <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking * income + age + gender, 
            family = binomial(link = "logit"), data = Obs.Data)

require(jtools)
results.model <- summ(fit.w.em, model.info = FALSE, 
                      model.fit = FALSE,
                      exp = TRUE)
results.model
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
\begin{table}[!h]
\centering
\begin{threeparttable}
\begin{tabular}{lrrrrr}
\toprule
  & exp(Est.) & 2.5\% & 97.5\% & z val. & p\\
\midrule
\cellcolor{gray!6}{(Intercept)} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{5.46} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{4.37} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{6.82} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{14.97} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{0.00}\\
smoking1 & 2.93 & 2.60 & 3.30 & 17.69 & 0.00\\
\cellcolor{gray!6}{income0} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{0.48} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{0.41} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{0.57} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{-8.28} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{0.00}\\
age & 1.29 & 1.27 & 1.31 & 36.77 & 0.00\\
\cellcolor{gray!6}{gender} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{0.54} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{0.43} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{0.67} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{-5.55} & \cellcolor{gray!6}{0.00}\\
\addlinespace
smoking1:income0 & 1.27 & 1.04 & 1.56 & 2.33 & 0.02\\
\bottomrule
\end{tabular}
\begin{tablenotes}
\item Standard errors: MLE
\end{tablenotes}
\end{threeparttable}
\end{table}
:::
:::



The interaction term in `results.model` is statistically significant.

### Presentation of effect measures {.unnumbered}

We can generate a summary report from aforementioned effect modification analysis. The table below depicts the adjusted odds ratios for income levels (`high = 0`, and `low = 1`)



::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-7_90349750bf1fe124cdeaacaf70fc8896'}

```{.r .cell-code}
require(interactionR)
em.object <- interactionR(fit.w.em, 
                          exposure_names = c("income0", "smoking1"), 
                          ci.type = "mover", ci.level = 0.95, 
                          em = TRUE, recode = FALSE)

em.object$dframe[,1:4]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
                             Measures  Estimates      CI.ll      CI.ul
1                                OR00  1.0000000         NA         NA
2                                OR01  2.9301604  2.6010653  3.3008937
3                                OR10  0.4832932  0.4068652  0.5740780
4                                OR11  1.7997639  1.6334908  1.9829619
5 OR(smoking1 on outcome [income0==0]  2.9301604  2.6010653  3.3008937
6 OR(smoking1 on outcome [income0==1]  3.7239584  3.1434919  4.4116118
7                Multiplicative scale  1.2709060  1.0385052  1.5553143
8                                RERI -0.6136898 -0.9754808 -0.2905171
```
:::
:::



## Effect measure assessment via stratified approach

This approach involves estimating a regression model in different strata of the effect modifier `income`:



::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-8_3fd6169da995d4b149d6c678fb8a9eb8'}

```{.r .cell-code}
fit.income1 <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking + age + gender, 
            family = binomial(link = "logit"), 
            data = subset(Obs.Data, income == 1))
fit.income0 <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking + age + gender, 
            family=binomial(link = "logit"), 
            data= subset(Obs.Data, income == 0))
```
:::



The table below summarizes the adjusted odds ratios for smoking across the different income levels (`low = 1`, and `high = 0`) as obtained using the stratified approach.



::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-9_c1e2e9e5cb9e3b511b871f7664f2db0a'}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
     Value of income exp(Est.)     2.5%    97.5%   z val.            p
[1,]               1  3.066878 2.707961 3.473366 17.64728 1.067842e-69
[2,]               0  3.590260 3.023124 4.263792 14.57113 4.287200e-48
```
:::
:::



Note that we can obtain the same results by estimating a regression model with an interaction term between the modifier and all covariates:



::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-10_c8cda735aebd9c2c9cf514def8a1e2aa'}

```{.r .cell-code}
fit.all.int <- glm(hypertension ~ income * (smoking + age + gender), 
                   family = binomial(link = "logit"), data = Obs.Data)

# Odds ratio for smoking in individuals with low income 
exp(coef(fit.all.int)["smoking1"])
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
smoking1 
3.066878 
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Odds ratio for smoking in individuals with high income
exp(coef(fit.all.int)["smoking1"] + coef(fit.all.int)["income0:smoking1"])
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
smoking1 
 3.59026 
```
:::
:::



## Interaction

Assessment of interaction between smoking and income. We estimate a logistic regression model where

-   Outcome: `hypertension`
-   Exposure variables: `smoking` and `income`
-   Confounders: `age`, `gender`, and `education`

An interaction term of smoking and income is added.



::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-11_6be32c9b01a5f46c0b054b7d2692f4e0'}

```{.r .cell-code}
fit.w.int <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking * income + age + gender + 
                   education, family = binomial(link = "logit"), 
                 data = Obs.Data)
results.int.model <- summ(fit.w.int, model.info = FALSE, model.fit = FALSE, 
                          exp = TRUE)
results.int.model$coeftable
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
                 exp(Est.)      2.5%     97.5%     z val.             p
(Intercept)      5.6937765 4.5570175 7.1141027 15.3077121  6.791105e-53
smoking1         3.3452459 2.9505339 3.7927612 18.8503257  2.920389e-79
income0          1.0908060 0.8506311 1.3987941  0.6849951  4.933470e-01
age              1.2981524 1.2804814 1.3160673 37.3150071 9.371499e-305
gender           0.5366777 0.4313229 0.6677666 -5.5815569  2.383750e-08
education        0.4233969 0.3502014 0.5118909 -8.8749618  6.995745e-19
smoking1:income0 1.1022535 0.8968615 1.3546825  0.9253438  3.547871e-01
```
:::
:::



The interaction term between income and smoking is, however, not statistically significant.

### Presentation of effect measures {.unnumbered}



::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-12_be7667191402865395f5b26849073c13'}

```{.r .cell-code}
int.object = interactionR(fit.w.int, 
                          exposure_names = c("smoking1", "income0"), 
                          ci.type = "mover", ci.level = 0.95, 
                          em = FALSE, recode = FALSE)
```
:::



Summary report from an interaction analysis when investigating association between two exposure variables (smoking and income) and hypertension. Below, `CI.ll` and `CI.ul` depict the lower and upper limits of the 95 percent confidence intervals, `OR11` = $OR_{A = 1, M = 1}$ , `OR10` = $OR_{A = 1}$, `OR01` = $OR_{M = 1}$ and `OR00` captures the reference.



::: {#tbl-effint .cell tbl-cap='Summary report from an interaction analysis when investigating association between two exposure variables (smoking and income) and hypertension.' hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/tbl-effint_b28762c1939b4f9c9b674576cbadfd0a'}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
                              Measures Estimates        CI.ll     CI.ul
1                                 OR00 1.0000000           NA        NA
2                                 OR01 1.0908060  0.850631061 1.3987941
3                                 OR10 3.3452459  2.950533888 3.7927612
4                                 OR11 4.0221386  3.287881778 4.9203713
5  OR(income0 on outcome [smoking1==0] 1.0908060  0.850631061 1.3987941
6  OR(income0 on outcome [smoking1==1] 1.2023447  0.997265811 1.4495962
7  OR(smoking1 on outcome [income0==0] 3.3452459  2.950533888 3.7927612
8  OR(smoking1 on outcome [income0==1] 3.6873089  3.112335708 4.3685026
9                 Multiplicative scale 1.1022535  0.896861546 1.3546825
10                                RERI 0.5860867  0.029944164 1.2657133
11                                  AP 0.1457152 -0.004274684 0.2598376
12                                  SI 1.2405887  1.008364517 1.5262937
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-14_2400ab44234a77e021fcc8c9f4bb5688'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# test run with additive model
Obs.Data$smoking <- as.numeric(as.character(Obs.Data$smoking))
Obs.Data$income <- as.numeric(as.character(Obs.Data$income))
fit.w.int.add <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking * income + age + gender + education, 
            family=gaussian(link = "identity"), data=Obs.Data)
sim_slopes(fit.w.int.add, pred = smoking, modx = income,
           exp = TRUE, robust = TRUE,
           confint = TRUE, data = Obs.Dat)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
JOHNSON-NEYMAN INTERVAL 

When income is INSIDE the interval [-3.27, 16.87], the slope of smoking is
p < .05.

Note: The range of observed values of income is [0.00, 1.00]

SIMPLE SLOPES ANALYSIS 

Slope of smoking when income = 0.00 (0): 

  Est.   S.E.   2.5%   97.5%   t val.      p
------ ------ ------ ------- -------- ------
  0.25   0.02   1.24    1.34    12.76   0.00

Slope of smoking when income = 1.00 (1): 

  Est.   S.E.   2.5%   97.5%   t val.      p
------ ------ ------ ------- -------- ------
  0.28   0.01   1.30    1.34    34.53   0.00
```
:::
:::



## Step-by-Step Guideline for Practitioners regarding Implementation

### Propensity score matching approaches

#### Stratified approach with exact matching within subgroups {.unnumbered}



::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-15_83116e428ec5432e0764cdde45523238'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# For income = 0
require(MatchIt)
set.seed(123)
Obs.Data <- sim(DAG = Dset, n = 5000, rndseed = 123)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
simulating observed dataset from the DAG object
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
match.income.0 <- matchit(smoking ~ age + gender, 
                            data = subset(Obs.Data, income == 0),
                      method = "full", distance = "glm", link = "logit")
data.income.0 <- match.data(match.income.0)
```
:::



Below, we draw a sample from the high-income group based on the hypothetical example of an association between hypertension and smoking. Here age \[centered\], gender, education, and diet are covariates.



::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-16_62811717bc546a763ca3231ff7518404'}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
            age gender education diet income smoking hypertension  distance
657   6.0810120      0         1    1      0       1            1 0.9999874
4932  1.6109860      1         1    0      0       1            0 0.9943155
252  -0.2475055      1         1    1      0       0            1 0.8525107
2693 -0.2511048      1         1    0      0       1            1 0.8516785
1646 -0.2836155      1         0    1      0       1            1 0.8439843
        weights subclass
657  1.00000000       36
4932 1.00000000       50
252  0.03296089       25
2693 1.00000000       25
1646 1.00000000        4
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-17_6608c55157956b0c06a3c4b30313dacb'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# For income = 1
match.income.1 <- matchit(smoking ~ age + gender, 
                          data = subset(Obs.Data, income == 1),
                       method = "full", distance = "glm", link = "logit")
data.income.1 <- match.data(match.income.1)
```
:::

::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-18_b2a7e84155005a118799c18d83c9c389'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Treatment effect estimation
fit.income.0 <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking + age + gender, 
                   data = data.income.0, weights = weights,
                   family = binomial("logit"))
fit.income.1 <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking + age + gender, 
                   data = data.income.1, weights = weights,
                   family = binomial("logit"))
# Robust variance calculation
require(jtools)
fit.nexp.adj.res1 <- summ(fit.income.1,  
                          robust = TRUE,
                          cluster = "subclass",
                          model.info = FALSE, 
                          model.fit = FALSE, 
                          confint = TRUE)
fit.nexp.adj.res0 <- summ(fit.income.0, 
                          robust = TRUE,
                          cluster = "subclass",
                          model.info = FALSE, 
                          model.fit = FALSE, 
                          confint = TRUE)
```
:::

::: {#tbl-stratified-approach .cell tbl-cap='Subgroup-specific treatment effect estimates (expressed in log-OR) from the hypothetical example using the stratified approach.' hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/tbl-stratified-approach_ec52f0f3b94e0c5be0ec0cf3c5879792'}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
     Value of income     Est.        2.5%     97.5%    z val.            p
[1,]               0 3.739945 -37.5789304 45.058820 0.1774046 8.591906e-01
[2,]               1 1.394520   0.9418774  1.847163 6.0383367 1.557109e-09
```
:::
:::



#### Joint approach without exact matching within subgroups {.unnumbered}



::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-20_0f38670659cb83fdcd4a597f0c1736ad'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ps.formula <- as.formula("smoking ~ age + gender + income")
match.obj.j <- matchit(ps.formula, data = Obs.Data,
                      method = "full", 
                      distance = "glm",
                      link = "logit")
match.data.j <- match.data(match.obj.j)
```
:::

::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/unnamed-chunk-21_18aa4bdebb7a1a0f7a0fe2414048541f'}

```{.r .cell-code}
fit.joint.no.exact <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking*income + age + gender, 
              data = match.data.j, weights = weights,
              family = binomial("logit"))
require(interactions)
nem.nexp.adj.res <- sim_slopes(fit.joint.no.exact, 
                               pred = smoking, modx = income,
                               robust = "HC1", cluster = "subclass",
                               johnson_neyman = TRUE, confint = TRUE,
                               data = match.data.j)
```
:::

::: {#tbl-joint-approach .cell tbl-cap='Subgroup-specific treatment effect estimates (expressed in log-OR) from the hypothetical example using the joint approach.' hash='chapter_07_cache/pdf/tbl-joint-approach_e2b1acc9907a5f8425af6b3e4ee41aff'}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  Value of income     Est.      S.E.      2.5%    97.5%   z val.            p
1               0 3.854853 1.0033297 1.8883628 5.821343 3.842060 1.220060e-04
2               1 1.401206 0.2805318 0.8513733 1.951038 4.994819 5.889087e-07
```
:::
:::
